Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Bilingualism and Executive Function: An Interdisciplinary Approach; CUNY Graduate Center-New York; May 18-19, 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Graduate Center of the City University of New York will host a workshop on the relation between bilingualism and cognition, with special emphases on executive functions and aging. A recent set of findings suggest that being bilingual confers cognitive advantages including a delayed onset for cognitive decline. The goal of this workshop is to explore explanations for how and why these advantages occur. There are a variety of different aspects of cognitive processing that may be enhanced by the experience of being bilingual and may therefore underlie reported advantages offered by bilingualism. Executive function in particular enables people to manage, integrate, regulate, coordinate, and supervise other cognitive processes, such as attention and visual perception. Bilingualism may be especially useful in enhancing some of those executive function capacities but may not be unique in providing those enhancements. Workshop participants will explore evidence for a single, high-level, description of how cognitive enhancement occurs versus many different underlying mechanisms that may each lead to enhanced executive function. This interdisciplinary collaborative forum will allow psychologists, neurologists, linguists, and neuroscientists to learn from each other and develop new approaches to this important area of research.

The workshop will consist of five discussion panels and a poster session. Each panel will feature two invited experts and a discussant. The panelists will be experts from different disciplines broadly divided into bilingualism and executive function. The disciplines include cognitive psychology, linguistics, aging, and neuropsychology. A poster session will provide an opportunity for students and young investigators to communicate their work on this topic to the workshop participants. Together the participants will discuss theories and mechanisms that might connect bilingualism and executive function. Cognitive health, extending into old age, is of increasing importance as the population ages. Understanding the role of bilingualism in the context of other cognitively challenging activities will have implications for public policy and public health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We organized and conducted a 2-day workshop on Bilingualism and Executive Function: An Interdisciplinary Approach. It took place at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York on May 18-19, 2015 (PI: Irina A. Sekerina, Co-PI: Virginia Valian). The workshop had an interdisciplinary focus as it brought together experts from different disciplines broadly divided into two areas, bilingualism and executive function. The disciplines included cognitive psychology, linguistics, aging, and neuropsychology. Each of the 5 panels featured two invited speakers, who are leading experts, and a discussant.

Panel 1: Introduction

Panel 2: Methodological Issues

Panel 3: Bilingualism and Cognition in Young Adults

Panel 4: Bilingualism, Linguistic Structure, and Executive Function in children

Panel 5: Bilingualism and Cognitive Reserve in Older Adults

Synthesis and Summary by Ellen Bialystok

 The invited speakers were Thomas Bak, Ellen Bialystok, Albert Costa, Harald Clahsen, Randall Engle, Naomi Friedman, Virginia M. Gathercole, Lynn Hasher, Raymond Klein, Judith Kroll, Jennifer Manly, Theodoros Marinis, Klara Marton, Antonella Sorace, Yaakov Stern, Joao Verissimo, Laura Zahodny.

Together 170 participants from 15 countries discussed mechanisms and approaches that connect bilingualism and executive function. The interdisciplinary exchange of ideas among researchers and students from different backgrounds that promoted collaborative research projects in the future took place during the poster session in which 120 young researchers in all areas of cognitive science and related fields presented 48 posters on bilingualism and executive function.

The workshop represented a truly interdisciplinary joint venture of scholars and set an important precedent for future collaborative solicitation of funding for such scientific gatherings from national grant agencies from the European Union and North America.

The workshop also had an educational impact on two levels: first, locally, it benefited the local students (CUNY, Columbia University, NYU, Rutgers University), and second, internationally, it attracted graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and junior researchers from different fields, such as aging, psycholinguistics, language development, brain and behavior, cognitive science, cognitive neuroscience, neurology, child language, neuropsychology, and psychophysiology, and from various countries.
